articles.headline: Michigan Vote a Test Case on Enshrining the Rights of Unions
articles.snippet: Unions in Michigan are asking voters to approve a referendum that would secure labor protections.
articles.abstract: Unions in Michigan are asking voters to approve a referendum that would secure labor protections.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Tired of battling legislative efforts to roll back union rights in state after state, organized labor is trying a new strategy: going on the offense. The first target is Michigan, the cradle of the United Automobile Workers and a bastion of union power.

articles.headline: Random House and Penguin Are Negotiating a Merger
articles.snippet: Random House, owned by Bertlesmann, and Penguin, owned by Pearson, are negotiating a merger that would create a publisher that would control 25 percent of the American book market.
articles.abstract: Random House, owned by Bertlesmann, and Penguin, owned by Pearson, are negotiating a merger that would create a publisher that would control 25 percent of the American book market.
articles.lead_paragraph: 8:53 p.m. | Updated  In an effort to stave off the challenge from online retailers in a rapidly changing market, two of the world’s largest book publishers, Random House and Penguin, are engaged in talks to combine their businesses.
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick and Eric Pfanner

articles.headline: Ford Closing 3 Plants in European Downsizing
articles.snippet: Ford broke from the pack of troubled European automakers, announcing deep cuts that include shutting factories in Britain and Belgium and eliminating 5,700 jobs.
articles.abstract: Ford broke from the pack of troubled European automakers, announcing deep cuts that include shutting factories in Britain and Belgium and eliminating 5,700 jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Ford Motor Company has broken from the pack of troubled European automakers, announcing deep cuts that include shutting three factories in the region and eliminating 5,700 jobs.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and David Jolly

articles.headline: Billions in Hidden Riches for Family of Chinese Leader
articles.snippet: It is unclear how much Prime Minister Wen Jiabao, who has staked a position as a populist and a reformer, knows about the $2.7 billion in assets his family has amassed.
articles.abstract: It is unclear how much Prime Minister Wen Jiabao, who has staked a position as a populist and a reformer, knows about the $2.7 billion in assets his family has amassed.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The mother of China’s prime minister was a schoolteacher in northern China. His father was ordered to tend pigs in one of Mao’s political campaigns. And during childhood, “my family was extremely poor,” the prime minister, Wen Jiabao, said in a speech last year.

articles.headline: Apple Profit Rises 24% on Sales of iPhone 5
articles.snippet: Apple’s profits were buoyed by sales of its new iPhone, which was introduced nine days before the quarter’s end.
articles.abstract: Apple’s profits were buoyed by sales of its new iPhone, which was introduced nine days before the quarter’s end.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the last five weeks, Apple has revamped its entire product lineup with new iPods, iPhones and computers. But on Thursday it said those products would be more expensive to make, nibbling into its ample profits.

articles.headline: Euro Survives, but Future Is in Doubt
articles.snippet: The real issue facing the euro is whether the peripheral countries can become successful economies while staying in the currency zone.
articles.abstract: The real issue facing the euro is whether the peripheral countries can become successful economies while staying in the currency zone.

articles.headline: Rethinking the Armory Show
articles.snippet: Exhibitions in New York and Montclair, N.J., will look back at the 1913 Armory Show, long thought to have shocked Americans with its displays of European modern art.
articles.abstract: Exhibitions in New York and Montclair, N.J., will look back at the 1913 Armory Show, long thought to have shocked Americans with its displays of European modern art.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 1913 — a few months short of a century ago — you are in New York City, not yet the world cultural capital. It’s a seething, manic place, with a powerful but provincial population. Wall Street is challenging London’s dominance of the international stock market, and finishing touches are being put on the highest high-rise on the planet, the Woolworth Building, in Lower Manhattan.

articles.headline: Transcript of 1944 Bretton Woods Conference Found at Treasury
articles.snippet: Unknown to historians, a transcript existed of the meeting of Allied nations during the heat of World War II, and three versions were in Washington-area libraries and archives.
articles.abstract: Unknown to historians, a transcript existed of the meeting of Allied nations during the heat of World War II, and three versions were in Washington-area libraries and archives.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A Treasury economist rummaging in the department’s library has stumbled on a historical treasure hiding in plain sight: a transcript of the Bretton Woods conference in 1944 that cast the foundations of the modern international monetary system.

articles.headline: Citi Chairman Is Said to Have Planned Chief’s Exit Over Months
articles.snippet: Once he became chairman, Michael O’Neill meticulously built a case for Vikram Pandit’s ouster, drawing in one person after another until Mr. Pandit had virtually no allies left.
articles.abstract: Once he became chairman, Michael O’Neill meticulously built a case for Vikram Pandit’s ouster, drawing in one person after another until Mr. Pandit had virtually no allies left.
articles.lead_paragraph: Vikram Pandit’s last day at Citigroup swung from celebratory to devastating in a matter of minutes. Having fielded congratulatory e-mails about the earnings report in the morning that suggested the bank was finally on more solid ground, Mr. Pandit strode into the office of the chairman at day’s end on Oct. 15 for what he considered just another of their frequent meetings on his calendar.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Susanne Craig

articles.headline: Bad Luck and Missteps Make G.O.P.’s Senate Climb Steeper
articles.snippet: Once viewed as likely to win the Senate, Republicans have at times made their own path harder.
articles.abstract: Once viewed as likely to win the Senate, Republicans have at times made their own path harder.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Indiana Senate candidate Richard E. Mourdock’s reintroduction of rape and abortion into the political dialogue this week is the latest in a series of political missteps that have made the Republican quest to seize control of the Senate a steeper climb.

articles.headline: Obama Campaign Endgame: Grunt Work and Cold Math
articles.snippet: The wave of passion that coursed through President Obama’s headquarters in 2008 has been replaced with a methodical approach to manufacturing the winning coalition — a more arduous task with no guarantee of success.
articles.abstract: The wave of passion that coursed through President Obama’s headquarters in 2008 has been replaced with a methodical approach to manufacturing the winning coalition — a more arduous task with no guarantee of success.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — This is what “grinding it out” looks like at President Obama’s election headquarters: scores of young staff members intently clicking away at computer keyboards as they crunch gigabytes of data about which way undecided voters are leaning, where they can be reached, and when; strategists standing at whiteboards busily writing and erasing early voting numbers and turnout possibilities; a lonely Ping-Pong table.

articles.headline: U.S. Growth Rate Picks Up to 2%
articles.snippet: More positive consumer activity and a healthier housing sector outweighed the effects of the drought, caution on the part of businesses and weaker exports.
articles.abstract: More positive consumer activity and a healthier housing sector outweighed the effects of the drought, caution on the part of businesses and weaker exports.
articles.lead_paragraph: More optimistic consumers are propelling the economy forward, even as businesses pull back.

articles.headline: Citigroup Pays Fine and Fires Star Technology Analyst
articles.snippet: Citigroup paid a $2 million fine and fired two employees after authorities accused the bank of improperly disclosing confidential information to media outlets about YouTube’s earnings and Facebook’s initial public offering.
articles.abstract: Citigroup paid a $2 million fine and fired two employees after authorities accused the bank of improperly disclosing confidential information to media outlets about YouTube’s earnings and Facebook’s initial public offering.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Randall Smith
